Swamp Creek Reserve is a small reserve right alongside the Peel River; the reserve is broken into two by Swamp Creek and is connected by a bridge on the road and a small walking bridge right beside the road. The side the Toilet is on is best recommended for big Rigs as there is a bigger turning circle area; the opposite side is suitable for Caravans and tents.

Because of the junction of the Peel River and Swamp Creek the water levels have been seen to rise quickly and the Tamworth Regional Council has advised of flash flooding in the area.

The area is well known for gold and gemstone fossicking and plenty of time can be spent in the water way panning for Gold. The local town of Nundle offers plenty of tourist attractions. The Woolen mill is a must for Australian Grown and Made Woolen products from yarn to clothing. The socks are even made right here at Nundle and a tour of the woolen mills is very informative.

SITE ACCESS
If leaving from Tamworth travel towards Nundle. The reserve can be accessed from either end of Rivers Road. The road is gravel, if coming from Nundle the distance is 2Km.

FEES & BOOKINGS
There is no charge for the use of this facility at the moment, so if you are staying at this site we encourage you to help keep it clean, and please visit and support the nearest town or village.

THINGS TO DO
In the closest town Nundle there are two antique stores, a homewares store, small grocers and takeaway shop, post office, Craft markets, op shop, leather shop, leadlight shop and classes, Café and Hotel.

The pool and playground are a hit with the kids. If you travel 11 Km east from Nundle to Sheba dams reserve you can swim, fossick, fish or just relax beside the water. There is also the Arc-En-Ciel Trout farm past the Sheba dams, fossicking for precious stones is also a fun way to pass the time.

FACILITIES
The Reserve is serviced by the local council. There are rubbish bins and a long drop windy toilet.
A large undercover area with table and chairs is very good if it is raining.
Drinking water – There is no drinking water.

RULES
Dogs are permitted on a lead and campfires are allowed following fire restrictions.

name: Gregories
description:
Lovely campsite in the Francois Peron National Park. These campsites overlook Shark Bay and are magnificent. Right on the waters edge they are widely spread and big enough to accommodate a group. Each site has a path that connects it to the beach where, I believe, the fishing is magnificent.
Definately need a high clearance 4wd as there are long stretches of soft sandy road. Air stations with compressors exist at the entrance t te sandy road. Let tyres pressures down by about 50% and drive to the conditions.
National Park Fees apply.
$11 per person per night and $12 Park Entrance fee.

name: North Mandu campground
description:
Small campground that has 5 sites. Close to Oyster Stacks and Mandu Mandu gorge walks. Also close to South Mandu day use area with great snorkeling opportunities. Tents can be used hete but pegs are impossible to hammer into the ground.
Camping costs $11.00 per person per night plus you have to pay Parks entry to the Cape Ranges National park.

name: Ningaloo Station - South Lefroy
description:
Campsites are scattered around the coastline of the sprawling Ningaloo Station. All campsites are on or very close to the beach. Literally steps away. Small dunes provide some protection from the wind. Magnificent snorkelling here as well as whale watching. For those who wish to cast a line the fishing is great as well. Must be self contained - portaloos are available to hire. Bring everything you need as there is nothing here.
Cost is $5 per person per night. Monthly rates are available - enquire at homestead.

name: Tiger Eye Pool / Creek
description:
Very basic camping just outside Tom Price. Easy access to Karijini National Park. Lots of lovely shady trees. Camp sites spread out along the creek bed.
Free Camp.

name: Nuytsland nature park
description: Bush camp off road .No facilities. Good overnight stop over

name: Brisbane Gateway Resort
description: Well organized campground with swimming pool. Most of the park is used for cottages, a relatively small section is available for campervans, motorhomes and caravans. Friendly staff. Individual sites are small and the place is near the highway resulting in continuous background noise. Washing machines and dryer available.

name: Agas National
description: Filled our South African bottles in minutes. Can probably handle many other connections.

name: Russel Transport
description: Russel Transport did our local handling in Brisbane for our car that was shipped from Europe. Our car needed additional cleaning before it was released. Russel was instrumental in organizing cleaning and new quarantaine inspections very quickly.

name: Tom Price free potable water
description: North side of square - opposite the TAFE campus. Free potable water available. Lots of pressure just supply your own hose etc.

name: Central Station- Fraser Island
description:
National Park established campsite. Designated sites most with wooden picnic table. Shower and toilet facilities. Need AUD $2 for hot shower. Drinking water available. Walk to Central Station Day use area. 
Tent or camper trailer spots. 
No phone reception available.

name: Cambroon Caravan Park
description: Spacious quiet terrain with dated, but clean and well maintained ablutions. Quiet environment. General Store with a very small range of products. Power always included in fee. Fee AUD 24 (2 adults, camper van).

name: North Shore Retreat Caravan Park
description: Large grass terrain with swimming pool. Dated ablutions. Hardly facilities for dish washing and manual laundry washing. AUD 40 per night (2 adults, camper). Showers AUD 1. Busy during holidays.

name: Warrigal Ridge
description: Friendly rural campground in beautiful environment with nice view over the area. We saw our first kangaroos here. Basic ablutions. AUD 20 (2 persons, camper van).

name: M.V. Beagle
description: One of the campgrounds near Inskip Point. Camping can not be paid on site, but needs to be pre-booked. A booking can be used for any of the Inskip campgrounds. Most of S.S. Beagle is accessible with a 2WD vehicle. No fixed places, but free camping next to the sea. Few facilities. Nice terrain under trees. AUD 13.20 (2 adults, camper).

name: Coolooloi Creek
description: Beautiful spot next to the beach, no amenities. Place must be booked beforehand and a vehicle permit is needed to access the island. AUS 13.10 (2 adults, camper van. High clearance 4WD access only.

name: Rainbow Beach Ferry
description: Ferry between Rainbow Beach and Fraser Island. Sales continuously. Outrageous prices: AUD 75 one way, AUD 120 return.

name: Galala (beach camping zone 2)
description: Along the east coast of Fraser Island an number of camping areas has been designated divided over different zones. Places must be pre-booked and are limited. A booking for a zone gives access to any camping area of that zone. The exact position of each camping are may change as parts of an area my be closed for regeneration. Accessibility is signposted on the beach. The areas can be reached from the beach only; this may be impossible when the tide is high. Careful planning is therefore important. The sites have no facilities, but superb views over the sea. Like the entire island the site is accessible with a high clearance 4WD only. Good Telstra reception. AUD 13.10 (2 adults, camper van).

name: Hook Point Inland Road
description: On maps (OSM, WikiCamp) this road is shown as a through road. However, north of this point it has become a footpath only. Vehicles have to go via the beach. In fact the only roads to the north are via the beach. As it is recommended to travel along the beach between 2 hours prior to and 2 hours after low tide you can be stuck for the night.

name: Maheno (beach camping zone 5)
description: Along the east coast of Fraser Island an number of camping areas has been designated divided over different zones. Places must be pre-booked and are limited. A booking for a zone gives access to any camping area of that zone. The exact position of each camping are may change as parts of an area my be closed for regeneration. Accessibility is signposted on the beach. Many areas can be reached from the beach only; this may be impossible when the tide is high. Careful planning is therefore important. The sites have no facilities, but superb views over the sea. Like the entire island the site is accessible with a high clearance 4WD only. Poor Telstra reception. AUD 13.10 (2 adults, camper van).

name: Happy Valley
description: One of the few places on Fraser Island where trash can be disposed of.

name: Hervey Bay Caravan Park
description: Large terrain with well maintained ablutions. Friendly manager. 5 minutes walk from ALDI and Woolworth. Swimming pool. Open between 8:00 and 18:00 (no late arrival access). Washing machines and dryers, but rudimentary provisions for hand laundry. Fee AUD 33 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Capricorn Caves Tourist Park
description: Friendly site next to the caves. Large spots under high trees. Well maintained ablutions. Washing machines and dryers, barbecues. Rudimentary facilities for manual laundry or dishes. A bit hard to find a level spot. Wifi near reception. All water is rainwater. Swimming pool. Fee AUD 30 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Cape Hillsborough Nature Tourist Park
description: Campsite with well maintained ablutions directly at the beach with nice views. Wallabies and Kangaroes roam the beach at sunrise. Various short nature walks (1.5 h) from the campground. 23m swimming pool. Fee AUD 29 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Fern Flat Campground
description: We intended to book Broken River Bush Camp, but it was closed due to reconstruction of the bridge. We booked Fern Flat which is appeared to be a lot nicer, because it isn't next to the main road, but in the tropical forest. The main advantage of Broken River is that you can see platypus from the campsite, whereas you have to cross 50 meter or so through the forest to the river from Fern Flat. There are 8 sites in total. Sites must be pre-booked. This can be done via internet or at the kiosk in the visitor centre next to the bridge. During booking you have to choose a site. Some sites are really inconvenient for campervans, because you cannot reach the site with the car. You will be bound to a small parking away from the site. Good sites are #1, #2 and #4. Hot showers are available in the village. No cellphone coverage. Fee AUD 13.10 (2 adults, campervan)

name: Wanggoolba Creek Ferry
description: Ferry sails 3 times or so per say and must be pre-booked. Information you find on internet about sailing times is confusing. We had the one at 17:00, but the one we found for 15:00 didn't sail. We paid AUD 130 for a campervan plus 2 adults. Call 1800 227 437 for bookings.

name: Glen Evin Farm Stay
description: The place is a farm with full, well maintained campground facilities. The powered sites are on a nice grassy field with large, shady trees. The unpowered sites are on a dusty field without trees between ugly buildings and rusty farm tools. The way we were welcomed was the least friendly of all our campsites in Australia: when we asked for a nicer place than the field with unpowered sites we were told "You can stand under that tree." It appeared that we had understood incorrectly which tree was meant; while we were setting up camp the lady came to us again and told: "You can go to the place I originzlly gave you, to that tree (the one she had apparently in mind) or leave." Eventually we had a nice place. Almost all guests were nomad pensionados. We were invited to the daily afternoon get together of all camping guests. Fee AUD 18 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Sultan's Kitchen Indian Restaurant
description: Good Indian restaurant with generous portions. We had the tandoori mixed grill; one serving would have been enough for the two of us. Bring your own alcoholic drinks

name: d'Aguilar National Park
description: Nice park near Brisbane, good public transport connection (bus 385). The small discovery centre with typical Australian animals isn't worth the entry fee (AUD 7.70), park entry is free.

name: Gympie Auto Care
description: Oil change and oil filter change for our Toyota LC HZJ79 while we waited. Quick service, good price. We got a substantial discount because the card reader didn't work and we had insufficient cash.

name: Alva Beach Tourist Park
description: Nice sites under high palms on grassy field. Washing machines and dryers. Good kitchen. Swimming pool. AUD 28 for campervan with 2 adults, no electricity. Swimming pool.

name: Jourama Falls Campsite
description: One of the two campsites in Paluma Range National Park. Large spaces under high trees. Pre-booking required, but no assigned sites. Near starting point of the walk to the waterfall viewpoint and swimming holes. Lots of mosquitos. AUD 13.10 per night (2 adults, campervan). No cellphone reception.

name: Etty Bay Van Park
description: Grassy fields next to the beach. Old, reasonably clean and reasonably well maintained ablutions. washing machines (AUD 4) and dryers (AUD 4). The place is visited by cassowaries. AUD 27 for 2 adults with campervan, no power. Internet near the reception building. Rudimentary dish washing facilities. AUD 20 deposit for shower key. Shop opens at 9:00 on weekdays, but keys typically can be returned earlier.

name: Airstrip bushcamp
description: Bushcamp on the end off the airstrip. Not anything going on there. Very quit good for an overnighter. Close to bittersprings

name: Goldsborough Valley Campground
description: Large terrain in the rain forest next to the river with spacious sites. Most sites have good shadow, some cannot be accessed by car and some are in thd dust of the gravel road. The best sites are #6 to #10. Sites must be pre-booked and are assigned at booking time. We arrived on a Saturday noontime; almost all places were in use although the preceding Friday no sites had been booked; apparently it is risky to rely on a place being available. No cellphone reception. No showers, but excellent swimming in the river. From the campground a beautiful walk through the rain forest can be made to the Kearneys Falls (2.5 km return). The path has many explanation signs of the traditional way of living of the aboriginals in this area. Fires allowed. AUD 13.10 for 2 adults and a campervan.

name: Tjapukai Aboriginal Cultural Park
description: We had the standard tour of about 2.5 hours and the 1 hour special tour in which all plants are explained. The latter was excellent: we had a very enthusiastic guide for the two of us who did not only tell about the plants, but also about the traditional way of living. The standard tour was much more touristy with spear and boomerang throwing by tourists etc. A lot could be learnt here as well, but we had to ask many questions to get the information.

name: Noah's Beach
description: Beautiful campground in the rainforest next to the beach. Almost all sites are good, although sizes differ substantially. Near the main road, but the road is quiet. Lots of shadow, some flies. Pre-booking required. Telstra reception on the beach.

name: Reef Magic Cruises
description: We made a reef cruise and also did the guided snorkel safari. At the Reef Fleet Terminal are 8 or so companies to choose from. Day tour setup is similar for all of them: snorkel equipment, swimsuit, coffee, tea, lunch included, visit to 2 places on the reef, total time available for snorkeling about 4 hours. We did the same tour 18 years ago. It was very beautiful, but we were shocked by the color difference: so much bleaching. We heard stories that the companies are more restricted in choosing the places to sail to to protect the reef and that therefore the most beautiful places aren't visited anymore. The snorkel safari takes you in a half circle further away from the boat with a maritime biologist. Her explanations were good (although snorkeling to see something, swimming against the current and listening to here was exhausting), but we saw little more than we saw at the general snorkeling site. Day tour AUD 149, snorkel safari AUD 39.

name: Cooktown Orchid Traveller's Park
description: Shady campground near the center of town with mostly pensionados. Well maintained. Good kitchen, washing machines and sinks for laundry. Swimming pool. AUD 35 (2 adults, camper, no electricity).

name: Ironstone Gully Falls
description:
Nice camping spot next to the falls. Campsites scattered through the trees. Lots of shade, fires allowed.
Free Camp. Free bbq plates.

name: Middle of nowhere
description:
A small sandy turnoff, hidden from the road. Leveled for tents or big(er) rigs. 
Windy but not as extrem as the coast.

name: Lakefield Ranger Base
description: At this location is a kiosk to book a campsite.

name: Kalpowar Crossing
description: Relatively open terrain with large sites and some trees for shadow. Sites are numbered and assigned as such. Like any Queensland N.P. camping sites must be prebooked. This can be done via internet or at the nearby Ranger Station. All sites are fenced off with bollards and fences. This makes it impossible to park a car on the site proper. Park is next to river. Nice 4 km walk from the park. Lots of birds and wallabies around the campsite. AUD 13.10 (2 adults, campervan).

name: Riverbend north of Coen
description: Beautiful isolated and quiet place just off the main road with shady trees at the river bed a few kilometers north of Coen. The river is dry at the end of the dry season. Good Telstra 4G reception. Free, no facilities. Access track may be a bit tight for big rigs.

name: Armbrust's General Store (+ fuel & ATM)
description: One of the two general stores in Coen; probably one of the last decent stores until Bamaca when heading north. Sells fuel and has an ATM. Apparently also a possibility to camp (alternative camping options across the street).

name: Chili Beach
description: Beautiful campsite in the tropical rain forest directly at the beach. Like all sites in the Queensland National Parks pre-booking is required. We had site 8: a large place well sheltered from the wind with some shadow. Places 11-14 have direct sea view, but also much more wind.

name: Coen drinking water
description: Just north of Coen is a place with free drinking water. Hose available.

name: Coen Sanitation Dump Station
description: Just north of Coen is a site with a sanitation dump station.

name: Hann River Roadhouse (+fuel station)
description: Large, sandy terrain with large trees. It can be dusty in the wind, but by the time you get here you will have seen a lot of dust anyhow. Next to the river bed. Places with good shadow. We were warned for the pet, a roaming emu that may snatch food from your table. Shop selling cold drinks and USB-cables. Hot showers and washing machines. Dish washing with hot water and light. Fuel station. Dogs welcome, but must be lashed at all times. Restaurant selling "station meals". AUD 20 for 2 adults + campervan. Generator electricity (limited hours included in price). Source water that locals drink without further treatment. Wallabies on campground.

name: Birds on Barron Guesthouse & Campground
description: Strange place that doesn't look like a campground. When you arrive you see one sign telling you to stay in your car, blow your horn and wait for the caretaker because of the dangerous dogs and another sign telling to go out and look for the caretaker around the corner. Nobody showed up, only agressively barking dogs. We left.

name: Trinity Plains Tourist Park
description: Well maintained campground with large, grassy sites. Little shadow. Friendly staff. Washing machine, dryer and provisions for manual laundry. Good dish washing with hot water and light. AUD 30 for 2 adults and campervan without electricity. Water at sites. Belongs to Kui Parks.

name: Mount Clear Campground
description: We checked in at the visitor center 47 km bevor we reached the campground, we went from north to south throw the NP. 2ppn/tent 12$. There are no facilities except toilet. They keeping water (available only after a lot of rain) in a watertank. Highly recommend place to watch Kängurus, they were always around us. Absolutely amazing there.

name: Split Rock Aboriginal Rock Art
description: The three rock walls with Aboriginal rock art at Split Rock are the only ones in the area that can be visited without a guide. Multicolor paintings of people and animals. The oldest inscriptions are said to be 11.000 years old. Total walking distance app. 1.5 km, entrance fee AUD 5.

name: Mareeba RV Potable Water Point
description: RV potable water point, picnic benches, waste bins.

name: Chillagoe Observatory & Eco Lodge
description: Large sandy terrain with tall trees offering a bit of shadow. Well maintained, clean ablutions. Small swimming pool. washing machine, dish washing possibility in kitchen. Bore hole water. Cold drinks. In season (April-September) restaurant, observatory and open-air movies. Electricity available at a few locations only. AUD 20 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Undara Experience
description:
SEASONAL CLOSING BETWEEN MID-NOVEMBER AND APRIL.

Very large, sandy terrain with lots of high trees that give some shadow. Well maintained ablutions, washing machines. Dish washing with hot water in camp kitchen. Excursions to the Lava Tubes to be booked from the reception; excursions are limited out of season, but are still available. Free wifi (after an annoying Facebook login session) near the restaurant. Telstra (only) reception at the reception. Friendly and helpful staff. Swimming waterhole. Vehicle fuel, sanitation dump station and gas cylinder refilling. Wallabies and lots of birds on the terrain. Nice, very well signposted walking trails. Also accommodation in old railway carriages available. AUD 32 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Undara Experience fuel
description: Fuel station providing diesel and petrol.

name: Cobbold Gorge Caravan Park
description:
THIS PLACE CLOSES FOR THE SEASON BETWEEN NOVEMBER AND FEBRUARY.

Also the gorge cannot be visited during this period.

name: Goldfields Caravan Park
description: Very nice place. Grassy terrain with trees giving much shade. Brand new, well built ablutions. When we visited (out of season) the reception was at the Georgetown Roadhouse, one block away. Lots of birds. Swimming pool opposite the street.

name: Georgetown Roadhouse
description: Well stocked supermarket to outback standards with reasonable selection of vegetables. Also has ATM and refills gas cylinders. Next door is a second, smaller supermarket.

name: Karumba Point Sunset Caravan Park
description: Terrain with over 160 rather small sites under high trees. The trees are mainly palms, beautiful but giving little shadow. Well maintained ablutions, swimming pool, washing machine, kitchen with dishwashing possibilities. About 100 meter from the beach. Tiny shop. AUD 26 (2 adults, campervan, no electricity, low season). WiFi near the reception. WiFi was fast, but will definitely be slower in high season. Also the facilities that were perfectly right for us are probably insufficient if all sites are occupied. The main drawcard of this campground is that it is next to the boat ramp. For most overlanders this will not be important. They therefore might consider one of the two campgrounds in the village, closer to shops and tourist attractions.

name: Croydon Centre Supermarket
description: Well stocked for the Outback but expensive supermarket.

name: BP fuel
description: One of two fuel stations in Croyden. No more fuel until Georgetown or Normanton.

name: Ash's
description: Simple restaurant offering dishes with locally caught fish. Excellent value for money: we paid AUD 44 for a seafood basket and a garden salat, more than enough for 2 people. Alcoholic beverages BYO.

name: Khancoban Lakeside Caravan Park
description: Fully equipped Caravan Park. Cabin available we paid for a double Cabin 2ppn/90$. Tent 2 ppn/28$. WiFi available. Very friendly and helpful staff.

name: Mohyu Caravan Park
description: It’s nice little Campground with kitchen, shower, toilets, washing Maschine and dryer Very clean and very nice spot. With a little pool. We paid 25/ppn tent. No WiFi. Pup and restaurant in front of the Campground

name: Mansfield Caravan Park
description: Very nice Campground, kitchen area, small swimming pool, very clean and new toilet and shower nearby the tent area. Laundry available. Friendly welcoming. Paid 38$ / 2ppn with tent. The cheapest Cabin is 110$/night.

name: Burkeville Caravan Park
description: Mediocre campground. Maintenance is OK. Most sites have high trees for some shadow. Expensive: there are no places with no power; we paid AUD 36 for 2 adults with campervan low season. Washing machines, one place for dish washing in the kitchen. The place is for sale. One hour WiFi near the reception building.

name: Carpentaria Fuels
description: This is the first fuel station after Normanton.

name: Carpentaria Fuels
description: Well stocked supermarket with a good selection of fruits and vegetables. Replenishment on Thursday.

name: SPAR - 5 Star Supermarket
description: Best stocked supermarket in town. Replenishment on Monday. We were told that it is also better than any supermarket in Normanton.

name: Nowlands Engineering
description: First fuel station since Normanton. Also very small stop and refilling of Australian gas cylinders.

name: Gregory Downs Petrol Station
description: Diesel and petrol. Next stations at Burketown (north) or Adels Grove (west).

name: Gregory Downs
description: Sanitation dump station just off the main road.

name: Burketown
description: Sanitation dump station just outside Burketown.

name: Post Office Hotel Motel & Caravan Park
description: Terrain with pebbles and islands with trees that give some shadow. Reasonably large sites. Aged facilities. Bistro/Pub and swimming pool. Washing machines, dish cleaning in kitchen. Directly along the highway with view on a fuel station. AUD 24 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Camooweal Drive Way
description: One of the two fuel stations in town. Also has a few groceries.

name: Adels Grove
description: Petrol to be filled before 10 am/noon because of vaporation.

name: Adels Grove
description: Sanitation dump station opposite campground Adels Grove.

name: Tennant Creek Caravan Park
description: Friendly campground with partly gravel and partly grass and trees giving some shadow. Powered sites only. Swimming pool, well maintained ablutions, laundry, kitchen with dish washing facility. AUD 32 (2 adults, campervan).

name: IGA - Tennant Creek Supermarket
description: Well stocked supermarket. Good place to replenish after an outback trip.

name: Rest Area
description: Parking on "Overlander Route" with 24 hour allowed camping.

name: RACQ - David
description: Workshop equipped for major repairs. Quickly and efficiently repaired tire. AUD 40.

name: Ponderosa Park Camping Area
description:
Large, grassy and fairly open camping area in Hanging Rock State Forest

The campground is made up of mainly grassy sites, and surrounded by a mixture of native trees and old pines. There are picnic tables, long drop toilets and wood barbecues.

This campground is probably a good alternative for those with a caravan or large camper as it has more room and larger, more level sites. There is about 8km of good quality dirt road to get in though.

Facilities and activities at Ponderosa Park
Number of sites: 30
Camping Fees: Ponderosa Park is free to camp.
Bookings: No bookings required. There is plenty of room and this is not usually very busy, so you shouldn't have a problem finding a spot.

Toilets:                   Longdrop or composting.
Pets:                       Pets are allowed with conditions
Water Availability: No water available at this campsite
Camp fires:             Fires may be allowed in built fire places. Please check local fire bans and rules.
Barbeques:             Wood barbeques are available. Bring firewood and check firebans.
Picnic Tables:          Yes

Access
This site is accessable by caravans in good weather.

Getting there
On the Nundle Road, about 17km east from Nundle (via Hanging Rock). The last 8km (from Hanging Rock) is unsealed, but good quality, and shouldn't be a problem in normal weather.

name: United
description: One of four fuel stations in Tennant Creek. Next fuel station direction Mount Isa is 250 km away. Fuel is much more expensive towards Mount Isa as well as Alice Springs.

name: Alice Springs Tourist Park
description: Large, friendly campground with reasonable shade and sites with sand and grass. Washing machines, swimming pool, small shop.

name: waterwheel tavern at lake tyers beach
description: Just go into the Restaurant and ask for Kev. he will show you where you can park free for one.night. We could use shower, toilet and energy too. He won' t take money so we went for dinner in his high recommended Restaurant

name: Tropic of Capricorn
description: 24 hour overnight allowed. Water and toilets.

name: Connor's Well
description: Picnic area with 24 hour overnight camping allowed.

name: John McDouall Stuart Memorial
description: Parking & picnic area with information about the area. 24 hour overnight camping allowed.

name: Peter Kittle Motor Company
description: Peter Kittle services Toyota, Mazda and Mitsubishi. They did an extensive 280,000 km service plus some extra repairs for our LandCruiser. They are probably not the cheapest, but it was a professional job without surprises. They told before in detail what they would do, how much it would cost and when it would be ready and committed to that. They offer a courtesy shuttle service.

name: Bluff Campground
description: Beautiful campground in Trephina Gorge National Park. Directly at the riverbed with great view over the mountains. Different short walks nearby. Not accessible for caravans and trailers. This campsite has the most beautiful view of the three Trephina Gorge sites. Gas barbecues and fireplaces. AUD 6.60 (2 adults, campervan) in honesty box.

name: Panorama Campground
description: Nice campground with view on mountains. Walks starting from campground. Gas barbecues and fireplaces. AUD 6.60 in honesty box (2 adults, campervan).

name: Gorge Campground
description: Nice campground with mountain view and short walk to the gorge Gas barbecues and fireplaces. AUD 6.60 in honesty box for 2 adults and campervan.

name: Desert Dweller Camping Gear
description: Great store for outdoor and camping. Better stocked than BCF.

name: National Pioneer Women's Hall of Fame and Old Gaol
description: A small museum with the life stories of many Australian women who played a pioneering role. The museum is located in the former prison of Alice Springs. Some cell blocks have been retained and can be visited. If you wish you can experience how it is to use the toilet of a male cell. In a few cells art made by inmates is visible. In some cells audio with the view of a director, a guard, etc. is played.

name: Ross River Resort
description: Grassy terrain with high trees giving reasonable shadow. Nice scenery. Old and not very clean ablutions, despite the few camping guests at the time we visited; we were told new ablutions are under construction. Washing machines and facility for dish washing. The place used to be a homestead and although very little farming is done today one can get a good impression of its history. Graeme, the manager, gave us an extensive explanation and showed photographs. Evening meals are set meals and need to be preordered. The small shop can provide bread, milk and drinks. Swimingpool. No GSM reception; (expensive) rural WiFi  offered. AUD (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Ross River Resort
description: First place to get petrol and diesel on Ross Highway after Alice Springs.

name: N'Dhala Gorge Campsite
description: Small terrain within the  N'Dhala Gorge National Park with a few sites offering some shadow. The surface is red gravel. Great view on the red rock from the campsite. The access road is 4WD only. When we visited the six river crossings were all dry; the main problem was corrugations. Fee AUD 6.60 (2 adults, campervan) in honesty box. Great sunset. The abundant wildlife consists almost exclusively of flies.

name: Arltunga Historical Reserve
description: Remainders of the Arltunga gold mine (1886-1913). Excellent information centre, buildings, machinery, cemetery. One mine can still be entered. The reserve gives a very good impression of the hard life of the miners in a very hostile environment. If you intend to visit the reserve as part of the Arltunga Scenic Drive it is best to co the scenic drive counterclockwise. The information centre then will be the first stop.

name: Bodalla Park Rest Area
description: nice place in the forrest close to princes highway for free. Great place for a walk or to see nature

name: Lake Moondarra
description: Lake situated 15 km from Mount Isa. It provides picknick facilities, waterski and large relax lawns. Lookouts and a scenic drive as well. A lot of different species of birds can be watched. Swimming is possible, although the water looks a bit dirt.

name: Wipe out bend (Gregory River)
description: Fantastic free spot along the river. Swimming possible. After well-sealed roads 1,5 km 4wd track. In wet season sometimes hard to reach.

name: Albert River Boat Ramp
description:
Near the boat ramp on Albert River you’ll find this free spot. No shade at all. Windy. 7,5 km north-east of Burketown. One toilet.
No swimming.

name: Bedrock Village Campground
description: This campsite’s got a lot of facilities. Shady pits on mostly grassy fields. Real good clean kitchen.  Shady pool. Clean sanitairy block. A lot of touristic attractions in high season. When we visited the place (nov. 2018) reception was closed. Choosed our own place and payed next morning.

name: Eureka Creek
description:
Pitches on (dead) grass. 5 huge trees will give some shadow. Near the creek wich provides running water also in the “dry”.
The road isn’t busy, but there is some traffic. No amenties. Only one rubbish bin.

name: PK’s Jungle Village
description: Very well maintained campground after a few “wild experiences”. Really good point to start explore Daintree NP, south of de Bloomfield 4WD track. Clean pool under the rainforest trees. Laundry and restaurant as well. Beside campground a lot of cabins, occupied by backpackers. Possibility to book a lot of tours. Near de beach.

name: Membinup Beach Campsite
description:
Lots of campsites spread along the coast just behind the dunes (very small dunes with dense scrub) Very sheltered spots seperate by bush. Shady and large,sites.
Free camp, please respect the environment and make no negative impact. Take out what you bring in.

name: Mount Ragged
description:
Small bush camp at the base of Mount Ragged. About 5 campsites dotted around the one toilet. Lots of trees providing shade and protection from the wind.
Free campsite but it is in the Cape Arid National Park so you are subject to the rules that imposes. No fires from 1st November etc. No dogs!

name: Ted Farhat Day Spot.
description:
Large open area with multiple shaded camping ares avaible. 
Free camp area.

name: Memorial Hall campground @ Coulta
description:
Camping area next to the Memorial Hall in Coulta. Large grassy area with some trees for shade. Close to the road but not much traffic so minimal road noise. 
Donations requested for the use of the facilities.

name: Barmera Park
description: Nice and quite Park close to the lake. Shelters, picnic tables, playground, drinking water, bbq and public toilets.

name: Tropical Breeze
description: Really great campground with very friendly managers. 300 mtr to beach where you van swim. A net provides protection against crocs and poisened jellyfish. Also 300 mtr to main street. Shady. Clean. Recommended.

name: Sandy Point
description: Big spot next to the river. Lots of campers. Shelters with picnic tables and bbqs. Running toilets. Sink to clean dishes. Pet friendly. Clean, quiet and safe.

name: Hay Visitor Information Centre
description: Free wifi. Free bike hire. Running toilets. Filtered drinking water. 2$ unlimited hot shower. Awesome!

name: Ellery Creek - Big Hole
description: Small campsite (10 sites) within the Western McDonnell range next to the Big Hole, a great place for swimming. Most sites have trees giving some shade. The place was busy: although we camped well after the tourist season and arrived at 15:30 we had a out the last available place. Well maintained ablutions. Free gas barbecue and picnic tables. Lots of insects (many different species). Fee AUD 10 (2 adults, campervan), payed in honesty box.

name: Standley Chasm
description: Beautiful chasm with walls formed 1.2 billion years ago. Unlike other gorges which are free of charge an AUD 12 entrance fee must be paid for access.

name: Standley Chasm Campground
description: The campground is a gravel area. It is also the parking for day visitors. Well maintained ablutions. Access to all walks is included in the camping fee. No shadow. Washing machine, dish washing facility, barbecue, picnic benches. Fee AUD 36 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Simson Gap Waste Collection Point
description: Place where waste can be disposed of. Within the National Parks are no waste bins. Visitors have to take all their waste with them.

name: Ormiston Gorge Campground
description: Large gravel terrain with little shadow. Gas barbecues. A few hundred meters from the waterhole. Fee: AUD 20 (2 adults, campervan).

name: Glen Helen Gorge
description: The first fuel station after Alice Springs on Namatjira Drive.

name: Palm Valley Campground
description: Shady campground with excellent facilities for a National Park. Beautiful environment. The access road is for 4WD only, but the section to the campground can be done with a 2WD with reasonable clearance. The section from the campground to Palm Valley definitely not. Gas barbecues, hot showers, dish washing facility. Many flies during the day and even more crickets at night. Fee AUD 6.60 per person (honesty box).

name: Palm Valley
description: Beautiful, lush valley with many palms in an arid environment. Access is by 4WD only. The first section up to the campground can be done in a 2WD with reasonable clearance, the last 4 km from the campground to the valley are so rocky and uneven that we decided to turn around and walk the last km to the starting point. From the starting points easy loops of one and two hours can be walked.

name: Ntaria Supermarket
description: Reasonably well stocked supermarket with some fresh vegetables and fruits. ATM.

name: Ntaria Fuel Station
description: First fuel station after Alice Springs on Larapinta Drive. Diesel is about AUD 0.25 per liter more expensive than in Alice Springs.

name: Mereenie Loop Road Permits
description: Permits for the Mereenie Loop Road to Kings Canyon can be purchased at the Ntaria supermarket.

name: Mereenie Loop Road Permits
description: For the Mereenie Loop Road a permit is needed. It can be obtained at Glen Helen Homestead.

name: Fink River Mission General Store
description: Reasonably stocked supermarket with some fresh vegetables and fruits as well as daily fresh bread. ATM.

name: Kings Canyon Resort
description: Terrain with quite some grass and some shady trees. Good swimming pool. Places for dish washing in addition to kitchens. Ablutions old, but well maintained. (Expensive) Rural WiFi available (AUD 5 for 100 MB). Alcohol permit for use in the bar. Washing machines and ATM. AUD 40 (2 adults, campervan, no power), credit cards accepted. Lots of flies.

name: Outback Oasis Fuel Station
description: Diesel and petrol. AUD 0.45 more expensive than Alice Springs.

name: Outback Oasis General Store
description: Small store with frozen bread, UHT milk and if you are lucky some vegetables. Stocks are replenished every two weeks. When we visited the vegetable shelfs were empty with no new supply to be expected for another week.

name: Permit needed for Mereenie Loop
description: A permit is needed for the Mereenie Loop section between the intersection with Road 6 and the Wanmarra National Park. A permit is valid for 3 days. We paid AUD 6.50 for 2 persons. There was no checkpoint on the route. Permits can be obtained in Hermannsburg, Kings Canyon Resort and Glen Helen Resort. See separate entries for exact locations. Reports were that this road was extremely corrugated (some maps even show it as 4WD only), but we could drive quite smoothly, most parts of the road 70-80 km/h.

name: Permits for Mereenie Loop
description: Permits that are required for the Mereenie Loop can be obtained at the Outback Oasis General Store.

name: Kings Canyon
description: The Kings Canyon walks are a highlight in Central Australia. Be aware that the Kings Canyon Rim Walk closes at 9 am and the Kings Canyon Creek Walk at 11 am on days that the forecasted maximum temperature is 36 degrees or more. The Rim Walk is classified as moderate to hard. After the very steep climb at the beginning the well signposted track is relatively easy with well formed paths and no loose boulders. It is recommended to bring 3 liters of water per person for this walk.

name: Yulara
description: The campground is on Ayers Rock Resort, the only place in the area for all Uluru and Kata Tjuta tourism. The campground is huge: 175 sites on sand or pebbles with good ablutions, washing machines, dish washing facilities and a nice swimming pool. On the terrain are trees and bushes, but they give little shadow. The shopping area with a well stocked supermarket, ATMs and restaurants is 15 minutes walking away. Free WiFi. At the time we visited WiFi was not working due to a Telstra cable failure that killed all communication including electronic payments to Yulara (we could make a credit card payment the old fashioned way). Fee: AUD 39 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Yulara Service Station (Shell)
description: Diesel and petrol. Price per liter diesel is AUD 0.42 higher than in Alice Springs.

name: IGA
description: Well stocked supermarket including bread and a wide range of vegetables and fruits. Extremely expensive.

name: Outback Pioneer Bottle Store
description: The only place in the area where alcoholic drinks can be bought to take away. Extremely expensive: the cheapest bottle of wine was AUD 32.

name: Mogas Fuel Station
description: The nearest fuel station outside Yulara.

name: Curtin Springs East Recreation Area
description: Parking and picnic area with 24 hour camping allowed.

name: Loritja Road Picnic Area
description: Parking and picnic area with 24 hour camping allowed.

name: Valley of the Winds walk
description: Beautiful walk of 7.4 km. The section to the Karu Lookout is grade moderate, the following sections are grade hard. The Karu Lookout can be accessed all day, the parts thereafter are closed at 11:00 am and also if the forecasted day temperature is 36 degrees or more.

name: NT-SA border
description: On the border between Northern Territories and South Australia is on the west side of the road a large rest area with toilet, picnic benches and water. 24 hour overnight camping is allowed. Across the road a short path leads to a large field with trees that give some shadow and patches of grass. The field is fenced and apparently intended as overflow area, but it is much nicer than the rest area itself.

name: Desert Oaks Resort - Shell
description: Fuel station and accommodation at the intersection.

name: Kulgera Fuel Station
description: First fuel station after intersection to Uluru when coming from north. Diesel is AUD 0.34 more expensive than in Alice Springs.

name: Kernot Range Rest Area
description: 24 hour overnight camping allowed. Water

name: NT-SA border
description: No fruits or vegetables can be taken from Northern Territories to South Australia. The nearest disposal bin is 160 km south of the border .

name: Oasis Tourist Park
description: Campsite with three different, fenced off sections: unpowered, powered and de luxe. All sites are gravel, some have a small roof for shadow. There are trees between the sections,  but they give little shadow. Ablutions are superb. Small covered swimming pool. Staff is friendly and helpful, but the use of facilities is not, because everything that is included in the fee elsewhere must be paid for: showers (only AUD 0.20 per 3 minutes), stoves, barbecues. Washing machine is available. Per day 500 MB WiFi per person is included in the fee. Water tanks cannot be refilled at the campsite, but at a filling point in town only for AUD 1.00 for 30 liters. Camping fee is AUD 27 for 2 adults, campervan, no power.

name: Cadney Park
description: Last place for diesel and petrol until Coober Pedy.

name: Marla Roadhouse - Caltex
description: Diesel and petrol available here. Diesel is AUD 0.16 more expensive than in Alice Springs.

name: Marla Roadhouse
description: Well stocked supermarket to Outback standards with bread and a relatively large selection of vegetables and fruits.

name: Swadling Reserve
description: Big car park. Shelters with bbqs and picnic tables, playground, water and running toilets. Short walk to the beach where you can find a shower.

name: North Shelly Beach Car Park
description: Car Park in front of the beach. Shelters with picnic tables. Building with running water and toilets. Cold showers outside.

name: Marla Roadhouse Fruit & Vegetable Disposal Bins
description: It is not allowed to import fruits and vegetables from Northern Territories into Southern Australia. Before the border in NT is a road sign informing that disposal bins are 160 km further south. That is at Marla Roadhouse where you find normal garbage bins. We obediently threw away our onion, but we didn't understand how imports can be checked, because at the same place is a supermarket selling... fruits and vegetables. We didn't come across a checkpoint.

name: Drovers Run Tourist Park
description: Large gravel terrain with a few small trees. The ablutions are good, the kitchen is a bit messy, but well equipped. Many flies. The place has also a car repair shop. Showers should not be used in the afternoon because the "cold" water is too hot. The place advertises with free WiFi. but it didn't work when we were there. Friendly owners. Fee paid: AUD 25 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: William Creek Fuel Station
description: The first fuel station after Coober Pedy or Marree. The place also advertises having bread and frozen meat. The campsite at the other side of the road looks shady, but we didn't check it out.

name: William Creek Sanitation Dump Station
description: Next to the public toilets is a sanitation dump station.

name: Breakaway Lookout
description: A nice tour can be made of about 75 km by following the road to Oudnadatta from Coober Pedy, turning left at the dog fence to the Breakaway and some other viewpoints and returning via Stuart Highway. Note that you need a AUD 10 permit that can be obtained from the tourist information in Coober Pedy.

name: Coober Pedy Tourist Information
description: Helpful and friendly. Permits for the Breakaways are sold here.

name: Coober Pedy South Side
description: Drinking water available. For AUD 1.00 you get 30 liters.

name: BP Service Station
description: One of the four service stations in Coober Pedy. Prices are at the same level as in Alice Springs.

name: IGA Supermarket
description: Very well stocked supermarket for this part of the world. We were told that it twice won a price for the best supermarket in South Australia.

name: Coober Pedy North Side Town Water
description: 30 liters of drinking water for AUD 1.00

name: Fuel Station Outback Roadhouse
description: First fuel station after William Creek, 202 km north.

name: Wilpena Pound Fuel Station.
description: Petrol and Diesel available. Prices comparable to Alice Springs.

name: IGA Express
description: Supermarket with frozen bread and meat, a reasonable selection of vegetables and fruits as well as beer and wine.

name: Drovers Run
description: At the Drovers Run campground is also a mechanic. We asked to fix a tyre, but replacement appeared to be necessary. The workshop was messy and the way of working not structured. When it became clear that our tyre couldn't be repaired (a 3 cm long stone had gone completely through it) we fortunately could buy a new replacement. However, no tooling for wheel balancing was available, so the job couldn't be finished. Although eventually the job was done well I would go to a different mechanic for any larger repair.

name: parking seagulls
description: quite free parking on a lake behind the seagulls club (only weekdays) restarea with tables

name: Waste disposal bins
description: In the national parks are very few opportunities for waste disposal, including no waste bins on park campgrounds.

name: Youngoona Campground
description: Campground with 4 sites only. Beautiful setting next to dry riverbed. No facilities. Few trees with little shadow. Sites must be prebooked via internet or at Wilpena Tourist Center. Fee AUD 15 per site. Park entry fee must be paid in addition.

name: Peterborough Caravan Park
description: Well set up campground with functioning and clean facilities. Good kitchen with dish washing sink, washing machines, small swimming pool, free wifi. Some sites with good shadow. Power, taps and drain at every site. Walking distance from township. AUD 25 (2 adults, campervan, power always included).

name: Steam Town Heritage Rail Centre
description: Fascinating museum of the rail history of Australia. In Peterborough met the north-south and the east-west railways. Visits by guided tour only. The tour lasts 90 minutes. It cycles between all items on display and therefore can be joined at any moment. No need to wait for the next tour.

name: Foodland
description: Very well stocked supermarket. The biggest one we have seen since we left Alice Springs.

name: Sanitation Dump Station
description: A sanitation dump station in the middle of town.

name: Drinking water
description: Free drinking water is provided at this place.

name: Free WiFi
description: Free WiFi is provided at this place in the centre of town.

name: Waste bins
description: Waste bins are provided here. No waste bins are provided in the Nature Park camp sites.

name: Starview Primitive Campsite
description: The terrain opened in 2017 is in a desert area with toilets, showers and free gas barbecues. There are 15 numbered sites for vehicles as well as tent sites. The vehicle sites all are on asphalt. This makes that the terrain doesn't give a nature park feeling. The facilities are very well maintained. Sites must be booked and cannot be paid in the park. Booking can be done at the Visitors Centre in Broken Hill and by phone (08 8080 3560). The fee is AUD 10.00 per person. The campground is inside the Living Desert park. An access fee of AUD 6.00 per person per day for the Living Desert can be paid at the park entrance. We had Telstra reception after we climbed on a hill next to the campground.

name: BP fuel station
description: One of the two fuel stations in Yunta. Note that this is the last place to get fuel until Broken Hill when you travel east.

name: Caltex
description: One of the fuel stations in Broken Hill. Note that Broken Hill is the last opportunity to get fuel until Yunta if you travel west.

name: Copi Hollow Caravan Park
description: Sites directly at the lake on green lawn. Ablutions reasonably clean and functioning. Water is pumped from the lake. Swimming in the lake is possible. Washing machines and dryers. Camp kitchen with dish washing facitity. Some shady trees along the lake. Helpful staff. Inconvenient system with a key for all ablutions. AUD 20 (2 adults, campervan, no power). Note that Menindee is in the Eastern Time zone 30 minutes ahead of the Central Time Zone of New South Wales.

name: Sculptures & The Living Desert
description: The Living Desert is about 12 km north of Broken Hill. Three interesting walks van be made: to a collection of modern sandstone sculptures on the top of hill with great views, a flora & fauna sanctuary like a botanical garden and a heritage trail with hides, important places for aboriginals, rebuilt aboriginal huts etc. The walks are easy and about 3.5 km in total. The sculptures can also be reached by car. Note that the flora and heritage trail close at 14:00 in summer. The AUD 6 access fee can be paid at the park entrance.

name: Copi Hollow
description: Collect key from caretaker at campground entrance and pay a fee.

name: Caltex
description: This is the first fuel station after Broken Hill.

name: Warrawong on the Darling
description: Lovely, grassy campground at a pond next to the Darling River. Sites directly on the water. Excellent ablutions. Washing machines. No shadow. Kitchen with dish washing facility. Beautiful environment and nice walk around the pond. Many birds and kangaroos. Fee AUD 28 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Liberty
description: One of the fuel stations in Wilcannia. One fuel station between Wilcannia and Broken Hill.

name: Little Topar Roadhouse
description: Mogas. This is the only fuel station between Broken Hill and Wilcannia.

name: PR & DM Slattery
description: Tyre repair and replacement only. Had our size BFGoodrich tyres in stock and fixed them quickly and efficiently. Open on Saturday.

name: Nyngan Riverside Tourist Park
description: Beautifully situated campground on the Bogan River. Grassy sites with shady eucalyptus trees (be careful with falling branches when the weather is bad). Reasonably maintained and cleaned facilities. Washing machines AUD 28 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Hermidale
description: Next fuel station east is in Nyngan (45 km), west in Cobar (87 km).

name: Inland Petroleum
description: Cheapest of the three fuel stations in Cobar. Next fuel station west 160 km, east 87 km.

name: Arthurton Overnight stop
description: Lovely sheltered spot behind the hall. Toilets and water. Pub just down the road for beer - food if the wife is here.

name: Smythesdale Public Gardens
description:
Very nice open area, lots of trees and grass. Tables and chairs scattered around the area. Off main road so there is a bit of road noise. Lovely small town to wander around and good meals at the pub.
Donation required and number to call to get code for the amenities.

name: rocky creek
description:
Free camp spot without facilities,
only one table with a bin.

name: little yabba creek park
description: free campground with facilities and 2 bbqs, nice grassy spot close to the river

name: Emmdale
description: Next fuel station east in Cobar (159 km), west in Wilcannia (100 km).

name: IGA
description: Medium size supermarket. The next ones are in Broken Hill (200 km west) and Cobar (260 km east).

name: Khan's Super Iga
description: Well stocked supermarket. Next supermarket west is in Wilcannia (260 km).

name: Coles
description: One of the large supermarkets in Broken Hill. Like in most Coles stores they have excellent apple pie and mixed seafood. Note that the next supermarket east is in Wilcannia (260 km).

name: Henry Lawson Caravan Park
description: Small park next to the entry road to town. The place was old and poorly maintained, but new management was busy with a very major refurbishment. Ablutions are completely redone and cabins are replaced with new ones. Washing machines, no kitchen, no facilities for dish washing. Equipment for WiFi was on order. Grassy terrain, many places with good shadow. The unpowered sites are right next to the road with quite some (also heavy) traffic in the morning making the place noisy at times. Quieter sites may be available once the rebuilding has been completed. For now it looks like the Gulgong Showground campsite is the better choice. AUD 20 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Gulgong Showground
description: Quiet site with facilities for sports events etc. that offers camping. Grassy terrain, partly with shady trees. No kitchen, no washing machines. AUD 12 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Spring Gully Camping Area
description: Enormous grassy campground directly at the river.  in Goulburn River National Park. Clusters of shady trees. One long drop toilet, picnic tables, barbecues. Great view and company of kangaroes and lizards. We arrived via the Mogo Road. It was recently graded and easy to drive. One steep section had an asphalt surface. Leave the main Ular-Wollan Road at -32.33751, 149.94565. Both entry to the park and camping are free. Overhanging trees on the Mogo Road may be a bit tight for big rigs.

name: Mudgee Riverside Tourist Park
description: Grassy terrain with large, shady trees. Aged but functional and clean ablutions. Washing machines. Walking distance from town. Fee AUD 25 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Mudgee Camping & 4WD
description: Camping and ARB store. extensive collection of gas adapters.

name: Sydney Tourist Park
description: One of the two campgrounds near Sydney. Into the city it is a 1 km walk followed by a 50 minutes train ride. Dated but functional ablutions, limited total capacity (only combined showers/toilets). The first nights we were on the overflow field; grassy with some shady sheets, but close to the road with quite some traffic. Washing machines and well equipped kitchen with the only sink for dish washing. Holiday season fee AUD 45 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: Metro Petroleum
description: First place in over 3 months travelling that managed to fill our South African bottles (without bleeder) to the specified value. It was done by letting the POL-adaptor leak a little and allowing me to regularly weigh the bottle to prevent overfilling.

name: Big Valley Campsite
description: A campsite on a private farm, big spaces for tents and caravans and camping cars. We needed power to charge our batteries and paid $40 per night, this was at Christmas holiday time and was actually a good deal! There are good facilities but it’s rustic and relaxed and very pet friendly. Really love it here!

name: John Tognela rast area
description: Wide rest area on both sides of the road. Possible to stay the night for FREE. Rubbish bins, Toilet and non potable water available. Plenty of space, close to the road but not noisy at night.

name: wild camping
description: nice place to Camp,  quiet, in front of Kakadu NP.

name: Lady Lizard Pink Creek
description: original place,  but with all. clean and quiet.

name: Blue Gum Flat Camping Area
description: Beautiful campsite in the forest in Morton National Park. Shade from high trees. The access road is a bit rough, but well manageable by a 2WD. 4 bays for 2 vehcles each (plus some places along the track if it gets busy). Even though it was the day after Boxing Day when we visited there was plenty of space while many campgrounds are fully booked at this time of the year. If the campground is full there is a second option at Yadboro Flat a few kilometers further north  along the Yadboro Road (Lat -35.34033 Lon 150.21727). A toilet and barbecue/fireplaces are provided. If  you follow the southbound walking track along the river for a few hundred meters you reach a beautiful swimming hole and a bit further a shallow rapid, also nice for swimming. Both the park and the campground are free of charge. Note that the westbound track across the creek enters private property through a locked gate; the only access to the campground is from the Yadboro Road.

name: North Kiama Rest Area (South bound)
description: Rest area near A1 on both sides 24h camping stay permitted. Free of charge. It is a driver revive place with free coffee if you are lucky south bound. Toilets

name: Mystery Bay Campground
description: Large terrain under high, shady trees directly along the beach with good swimming and beautiful beach walk opportunities. Only facilities are a few long drop toilets, a few cold showers and water taps without drain. The place is superb during quiet times, but has insufficient ablutions for the large number of guests in peak season. Peak season price AUD 34 (2 adults, campervan). Low season price is AUD 24 (pensioners AUD 18).

name: Cobargo Motel
description: Lawn behind the motel, far enough away from the main road to be quiet. Short walking distance to village. Camping for self contained vehicles is free and for AUD 5 per person per night toilet and shower are available and can WiFi and swimming pool be used. Coin operated washing machines and dryers as well as a sanitation dump station are provided. Friendly place. Even on new years eve ample space was available. Good bakery in the village, but a very basic grocery store only (you need to go to Bermagui).

name: Toomulla beach camping area
description: nice free campground for 48h, grassy spots, bbq, siting areas, some trees for shadow

name: Point Road, camping area
description: Basic camping area on a 4WD road, in the trees and $8 per person per night

name: Somerview Cottage
description:
Cute Airbnb. https://abnb.me/Lyp4nzHZaT
Very friendly owners. If it’s not let out to guests and they themselves are staying there, will probably let you overnight in your rig for free. Contact cottagesomerview@gmail.com

name: Cobargo sanitation dump station
description: Key can be obtained from the adjacent Cobargo Motel after 10 am.

name: Six Mile Creek Campground
description:
In South East Forests National Park. Large campground in the forest under high, shady trees. Big sites that can be shared between 3 or 4 cars if it is busy. Long drop toilet and fire places. Rain water container. Beautiful 300 meter boardwalk to waterfall. There are waterholes in the creek, but they require some rock climbing. Access via an excellent gravel road. Both park access and campground are free of charge. Apart from the boardwalk there are no other walks around the campground. No mobile reception.

bookings required

name: Nunnock Campground
description: Beautiful campground under high trees in the South West Forest National Park. Three large bays that can share a number of vehicles if it is busy. Long drop toilet and fire places. Different walking tracks nearby. Water from rain water container. Park access and camping are free of charge. Although we visited in the peak season we had the site almost ourself. No mobile reception.

name: Goongerah Camping Ground
description: Beautiful campground on the west side (but out of) the Errinundra National Park next to the Brodribb River. Large, grassy sites under high shady trees at both sides of the river. Pit toilet and picnic benches.  The shallow river is good to let children play and for cooling, but not so much for swimming. Secluded places are available if you accept some walking distance to the toilet. One walk leaves from the campground (11 km, one way, steep - we didn't walk it). Park access and camping are free of charge. No mobile reception.

name: Caltex
description: Only one fuel station between Bombala and Orbost in Delegate.

name: Delegate Motors
description: Next fuel station south is not earlier than Orbost.

name: Macrossan Camping Area
description: large place to stay for 1 till 7 night free. good place to see the stars. near by the road A6 and close to a river. wildlife on place

name: Orbost Caravan Park
description: Grassy campground with lots of shady trees. Well maintained facilities. Washing machines, dish washing place, sanitation dump station. River with place suitable for swimming a few minutes walking south along the road from the campground. Some road noise. Walking distance to shops in town. AUD 34 (2 adults, campervan, no power).

name: United
description: Last fuel station until Delegate when traveling north.

name: Marlo Caravan Park & Motel
description: Small campground with fixed, powered sites only on manicured lawns. Short distance from Snowy River and next to General Store. Sites partially shady. Well maintained ablutions. Gas barbecues, but no kitchen. AUD 40 (2 adults, campervan).

name: Bally Hooly Campsite
description: Campsite in Snowy River National Park, a few minutes walking from the Snowy River. Two longdrop toilets, no other facilities. Grassy terrain surrounded by trees, few shady places. When we visited in the peak season it became really full with eventually 29 cars and many tents; be early for a good spot! Good but narrow gravel access road (traffic in the opposite direction can be challenging). Park access and campground are free. Limited Telstra reception. The first river access leads to a point with lots of boulders and a strong current. If you continue walking along the river for a few hundred meters you arrive at a small beach and a sandy river access without current. One walk of about 1.5 km starting at the campground can be made. It is best to walk clockwise: the path is a little overgrown for a small section in the middle and you may miss it when walking counterclockwise.

name: Buchan Caves Reserve
description: Grass terrain with many shady trees next to the Buchan Caves Visitor Centre. Well maintained ablutions. The place called kitchen has picnic tables and dishwashing sinks, nothing else. Prices are per site (up to six persons): peak season no power AUD 59.10.

name: Snowy River Banks
description: At this side of the Snowy River are six or so picnic places and parking areas south of Orbost that are used for camping. They are directly next to the river and most of them also directly next to the Orbost - Marlo road; we saw one with bushes between the road and the parking. No facilities, free.

name: Bruntons Bridge
description:
Beautiful campground at both sides of the Thomson River and next to the legacy Bruntons bridge that is a pedestrian bridge now. The main campground is on the Walhalla (northwest) side of the river. Camping is possible directly by the riverside, at two elevated sites between the river and the road (these are the best places) and at the other side of the road. There are long drop toilets, but no other facilities here. On the southeast side across the pedestrian bridge are a few more campsites, but no toilets. Vehicles have to cross the river via a fort of about 50 cm deep. No GSM reception. The campsite is free of charge.

A walk of a 4 km loop can be made by following the upward track from the southeast side of the campground. The track splits after a few hundred meters and the two tracks join again after about 2 km. The western track has some steep sections; therefore it is easiest to walk counterclockwise.

name: Park Land Holiday Park
description: Campground belonging to the Big4 chain and the most expensive campground of our trip until now. Sites are laid out for caravans and consist of a piece of gravel, a slab and a piece of grass. Beautiful amenities. Washing machines,  swimming pool, barbecues, no wifi. Power is always included. AUD 60 (2 adults, campervan).

name: Kenneth River Holiday Park
description: Campground of the TOP chain, very busy in the holiday season. Grassy, mostly shaded sites, beach across the road. Well maintained ablutions, washing machines, barbecues, dish washing sinks. Free but sllw wifi. Water from the taps is non potable, but drinking water is provided from one tank. No Telstra reception. On the road behind the the campground you can see lots of King Parrots as well as koalas. Fee (peak season): AUD 60 (2 adults, campervan, unpowered).

name: carpark at moto-racing-area
description: free carpark at a moto-racing-area, no facilities, close to the beach, you can stay during the day with your car on the beach but not camp there

name: Beauchamp Falls Reserve Campground
description: The campground consists of a busy, dusty parking lot that is used by day visitors to the Beauchamp Falls and a lawn. The parking lot is enclosed by bullocks, therefore the only camping option for cars is the parking lot. It may be a challenge to find a level spot. The campground is surrounded by high trees. Two long drop toilets are provided, no other facilities. The 2.5 km 1.5 hour walk to the falls is great. Part of the approach road from the east is very beautiful, but winding and narrow. Access to the Beauchamp Falls Reserve as well as camping is free. No Telstra reception.

name: Beauchamp Falls
description: Stunning falls between large farns in the rain forest. A walk of 2.5 km 1.5 hours return can be made from the parking lot/campground through rain forest with high trees and big farns to the 25 m falls in a beautiful rain forest setting. The narrow, winding access road from the east is beautiful as well.

name: Aire Crossing
description:
Beautiful small campground next to the Aire River in the rain forest in Great Otway National Park. Long drop toilet and non potable water provided, no other facilities. The river is suitable for swimming. It is a challenge to find a level spot. Park access and campground are free of charge. No Telstra reception.

We accessed the campground via the Phillips track. Although it is signposted as 4WD only it is passable by almost any vehicle (at least when it is dry).

name: Triplet Falls
description: Beautiful walk (2 km - 1 hour) through rainforest to the falls. Also the longer (2.5 km, 2.5 hours) Little Aire Falls walk can be made from here.

name: Timboon Recreation Reserve
description: The reserve consists of a oval for sports events with a large, well maintained, grassy area around it where camping is allowed at a quiet location. Although it is close to the 12 Apostels, there was plenty of space, even in peak season. One dressing room is open with a toilet in it and a second room with a hot shower. Access is by donation (1 gold coin = AUD 1 or 2 suggested). Good Telstra reception.

name: Timboon Recreation Reserve
description: Sanitation dump station in front of the sports fields building. Users are requested to donate a gold coin (AUD 1 or 2) in the honesty box at the sports field entrance.

name: Gum Tree Caravan Park
description: Well maintained campground with new ablutions and a well equipped kitchen. Grassy sites with little shadow. Some noise from the Princess Highway. Washing Machines. Free wifi 500 MB per person per day. AUD 40 (2 adults, campervan, no power, peak season).

name: Broken Creek Bushcamp
description: Nice established campground, toilets, showers

name: Stevenson Falls
description: Free Campground, next to Stevenson Falls

name: Griffith Island
description: On the island lives between November and April a Mutton Bird ( Wedge-tailed Shearwater) colony of some 2000 animals. They hatch mid January. Their nests are in burrows. During the day the adults are foraging at sea, shortly after sunset they return en masse to the colony. In the winter period they make a tour of some 15.000 km to Japan, Alaska and California.

name: Annya Camp
description: Large grassy area surrounded by and partly under high trees. Long drop toilet, no other amenities. Picnic benches, fireplaces, shelter. Marked walk of 3 km around swamp next to campground. There is a bird hide, but we didn't see any birds. We did see wallabies, but not the koalas that are supposed to be here. Free of charge. Good Telstra reception.

name: River Vu Park
description: Small family run campground with grassy sites directly on the Glene'g River. Well maintained amenities. Friendly and helpful staff. AUD 21 (2 adults, campervan, no power). No walks directly from campground.

name: Nelson Kiosk & General Store
description: More a snackbar than a general store. Bread, but no vegetables.

name: Livingstone Island Nature Walk
description: The easy walk of 2.5 km (1.5 hours) is located within Discovery Bay Coastal Park with views of the Glenelg River estuary, salt marsh areas and scrub land. On the trail are a number of good bird watching opportunities.

name: Hacks Lagoon Conservation Park
description: Great place! Large, grassy terrain with high, shady trees next to the lagoon. Lots of birds. Flush toilet, barbecue, no other amenities. Walks (Gunawar Walk, Pat Om Walk) from the campsite. Fee AUD 20 per vehicle per night with up to 8 persons. Park access AUD 10 per day if you don't have a park pass. The honesty box at the park entrance is only for park access, campsites must be booked online although there are no designated sites. Website and phone numbers  an be found at the information shelter at the entrance Telstra reception is good.

name: Tarpeena Sanitation Dump Station
description: Sanitation dump station almost next to the picnic area.

name: Border Crossing Victoria and South Australia
description: Note that it is not allowed to bring fruits and vegetables into South Australia. Disposal bins are provided at the border. We were not checked when we travelled to South Australia.

name: Bool Lagoon Lap
description:
The ranger recommended us to make a lap around the Bool Lagoon. It was beautiful with many birds; around the lagoons are 150 species of birds. At different points are boardwalks and bird hides. The route we took is 
Bool Lagoon Access Road
Lindsey Hoods Road
Moyhall Road
Then take the first turnoff right after the junction with Limberts Road  (not on OpenStreetMap) 
Follow the track to join Vines Road and turn right
Enter the track right at the first fence (not on OSM)
Follow the track until you join Bool Lagoon Access Road

Some of the tracks are signposted as 4WD only. If it is dry high clearance is sufficient. Neither Google Maps nor OSM are correct: Google shows tracks that don't exist (ending in farmland), OSM doesn't show all tracks. I will add the missing tracks in OSM as soon as I am back home.

name: Kingston Foreshore Caravan Park
description: The campground is a 100 meters from the beach. 25% of the powered sites have good shade, the rest and all unpowered sites are in the sun. Reasonably well maintained amenities. Washing machines. Unpowered sites are AUD 26 in peak season powered sites AUD 43. unpowered 21.50 off peak. Wifi is temperamental (always)

name: Wills Beach Shack
description: Beautiful place! Large, grassy terrain directly behind the dunes to the sea. Lots of bushes, but little shadow. Simple but new ablutions. Washing machines by donation (AUD 3 suggested). AUD 20 (2 adults, campervan).

name: Kingston SE RV Park
description: Community run arra, tents not allowed. AUD 10 for a stay of up to 48 hours. Drinking water. No shade. Flat, open terrain directly the sea. pay via ticket machine

name: 42 Mile Crossing Camp
description:
Large terrain with large patches of grass just behind the dunes. New toilets, water shelter and a few picnic benches. Few places with shade. Some Telstra reception. Walking track and 4WD track to the beach (1.5 km). 2WD access to campsite. 4WD driving on the beach is possible and allowed for most of the year.  
1/10/2020 $16.50 per site reserve and pay online

name: Wellington Caravan Park
description: Campsite with relatively many cabins and a small, separate part with powered sites. We had a nice, shady unpowered site on a lawn near the entrance. Well maintained ablutions, small kitchen, washing machines, dish washing facility. Water from the main taps is not drinkable, rainwater is available from a container. AUD 24 (2 adults, campervan, unpowered). Good Telstra reception. Pub serving food across the road.

name: Lake Albert Caravan Park
description: Large terrain with nice sites next to the lake. Some sites with shade. The unpowered sites are at the back of the campground, quite far from the amenities (apart from a few toilets). Wifi 100 MB per 24 hours. AUD 20 (2 adults, campervan, unpowered).

name: Adelaide Caravan Park
description:
Small park on walking distance through the park to the CBD. Shady sites, some along the river. Modern, well maintained amenities. Washing machines, dish washing place, swimming pool, sanitation dump station. Only powered sites. Very expensive: we paid AUD 64 for 2 adults with campervan during the Australia Day weekend; standard rate is AUD 48. A 10% is offered for next bookings; we used that immediately and therefore paid AUD 43.20 per night for the next 2 nights. Good Telstra reception.

Bus line 98A and 98C into town are free of charge, other buses must be paid for. The nearest line 98 bus stop is at the Provost Street / Jenningham Street intersection (-34.90858, 138.60650).

name: Bike SA
description: At 14 places in Adelaide it is possible to borrow a bicycle for free for a day. You need to leave a photo ID as deposit. The locations can be found here: https://www.bikesa.asn.au/adelaidefreebikeslocation. We used the outlet at the zoo (coordinates of this entry), the place closest to the Adelaide Caravan Park. The weather was super and we made a nice ride along the river. It looks like Adelaide is all park.

name: Tingalpa Creek boat ramp
description: Ideal overnight for self contained. Quite and next to the water may be some people fishing near the ramp or boats launching early morning. There is a toilet near by and a tap for water (need your own tap key)

name: Morwell River camping
description:
Nice open place flat area between the road and the the river. Plenty of spots under trees and also the flat open space in the middle. About 5 kms from the small town of Boolarra. No amenities or services of any kind.
Free Camp...

name: Campsite C18 - Ninety Mile Beach
description:
Lovely open shaded campsite between the road and the beach. Room for many vehicles and a very short walk to the beach - over 1 dune. There are about Twenty campsites alongside 90 Mile Beach, each one with multiple camp spots. Some have toilets some have not.
Free camping

name: Central Market
description: Market of permanent stalls with mainly food. High quality and nicely displayed, but certainly not less expensive than neighbouring Coles. Don't expect a traditional Mercado Municipal.

name: Auburn Community Caravan Park
description: Small gravel terrain with powered sites and large grassy terrain with unpowered sites, both offering quite a good portion of the sites with high, shady trees. Modern, well maintained and clean amenities, well equipped kitchen. Gas barbecue. Fee is AUD 18 (2 adults, campervan, no power) before 10% CMCA discount. Cash only. It is amazing to see how well this community campground is run by Eric and Helen, a retired volunteer couple.

name: Taminga Hotel
description: Lunch Special for AUD10. Includes roast or pie of the day, vegetable buffet, salad buffet and icecream. We had lamb and a peppered chicken pie. Excellent value for money.

name: Heron's Bend Nature Reserve
description: Located near a hamlet called Overland Corner. Beautiful, large campground under high gum trees (take care where you put your vehicle or tent to avoid being hit by falling branches). Sites directly next to the Murray River with pelicans and other birds. Long drop toilets, rainwater tank, no other amenities. Free of charge. Good Telstra reception.

name: Riverland Quarantine
description: No fruits or vegetables to be taken beyond this point into Riverland (eastbound). Bins are provided. We didn't come across a checkpoint.

name: Wellington
description: Wellington sanitation dump station next to ferry.

name: Pinnaroo Caravan Park
description: Small campground with some large, shady trees. Amenities are old and need maintenance. We saw a sign "Upgrade in progress" but not much evidence of that.
